contentrichtext.text: {{distinguish|Heinrich Christian Friedrich Schumacher}} [[Image:Heinrich Christian Schumacher.jpg|thumb|200px|Heinrich Christian Schumacher]] '''Heinrich Christian Schumacher''' (September 3, 1780 – December 28, 1850) was a [[Germany|German]]-[[Denmark|Danish]] [[astronomer]]. ==Biography== He was born at [[Bad Bramstedt|Bramstedt]], in [[Duchy of Holstein|Holstein]], and studied at [[Kiel]], [[Jena]], [[Copenhagen]], and [[Göttingen]]. In 1810, he became adjunct professor of astronomy in Copenhagen. He directed the [[Mannheim]] observatory from 1813 to 1815, and then became professor of astronomy in Copenhagen. From 1817 he directed the triangulation of Holstein, to which a few years later was added a complete [[Geodetic surveying|geodetic survey]] of [[Denmark]] (finished after his death). For the sake of the survey, an observatory was established at [[Altona, Hamburg|Altona]], and Schumacher resided there permanently. He was chiefly occupied with the publication of ''Ephemerides'' (11 parts, 1822–1832) and of the journal ''[[Astronomische Nachrichten]]'' (founded by himself in 1821 and still being published), of which he edited thirty-one volumes. In 1827 he was elected member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]], and in 1829 he won the [[Gold Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society]]. His [[portrait]] now hangs in the Development Office of [[the Royal Society]]. ==Family== His son, '''Richard Schumacher''' (1827–1902), was his assistant from 1844 to 1850 at the conservatory at Altona. Having become assistant to [[Carlos Guillermo Moesta]] (1825–1884), director of the observatory at [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago de Chile]], in 1859, he was associated with the [[Chile]]an geodesic survey in 1864. Returning in 1869, he was appointed assistant astronomer at Altona in 1873, and afterwards at [[Kiel]]. H. C. Schumacher's nephew, '''Christian Andreas Schumacher''' (1810–1854), was associated with the geodetic survey of [[Denmark]] from 1833 to 1838, and afterwards (1844–1845) improved the [[Pulkowa Observatory|observatory at Pulkowa]]. ==References== This article incorporates text from publications now in the [[public domain]]: *{{Cite EB1911|Schumacher, Heinrich Christian}} *{{Cite NIE|Schumacher, Heinrich Christian|year=1905}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Schumacher, Heinrich Christian | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = German-Danish astronomer | DATE OF BIRTH = September 3, 1780 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Holstein | DATE OF DEATH = December 28, 1850 | PLACE OF DEATH = Altona, Hamburg }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schumacher, Heinrich Christian}} [[Category:1780 births]] [[Category:1850 deaths]] [[Category:People from Bad Bramstedt]] [[Category:People from the Duchy of Holstein]] [[Category:German astronomers]] [[Category:Danish astronomers]] [[Category:Recipients of the Gold Medal of the Royal Astronomical Society]] [[Category:Members of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Foreign Members of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Corresponding Members of the St Petersburg Academy of Sciences]]
